Subject: Re: [junit] chosing between jmock and easymock for mocks?

Thanks for your reply, it cleared some things out for me and in some
we jus=
t have different experiences, opinions and preferences, I guess.

<snip>

>=
 There is probably no one answer to that question. There is no question
> t=
hat EasyMock is, well, easier. (It's in the name after all.) But
> readabil=
ity and refactorability of the code is not the only factor in
> determining=
 which is better. I think you're forgotten that jMock has
> more features a=
nd flexibility than (at least) EasyMock 1.x. (I could be
> wrong, because I=
 haven't touched EasyMock since early 2004.)

Just to clarify, I'm not usin=
g EasyMock, I'm using rMock the only
thing I can compare is a record/play f=
ramework to a declare framework
such as jMock.

I have not worked actively =
with EasyMock enough to have an opinion, I
have read the documentation and =
looked at the examples, in the 2.0
online documentation it is a bit more em=
phasized how to extend it but
if focuses mainly on the new 1.5 features, in=
 the 2.0 documentation I
recognized more things from jMock in EasyMock but =
I don't know if they
have always been there and are just brought more to my=
 attention now.
It is possible that I would like jMock more than EasyMock, =
i picked
jMock over EasyMock once upon a time espesially after reading the
=
jMock vs EasyMock comparison on the jMock site.

At the moment I am using a=
nd developing rMock 2.0. In terms of
flexibility and readability I have wha=
t I need there, some things are
more flexible than jMock some things are le=
ss flexible but imo it is
atleast as readable.

The featureset and clairity=
 of rMock suits me but that is not a big
surprise since I participate in it=
s development. I espesially like
that all tests tend to have the same struc=
ture in rMock (this is
driven by the fact that rMock allows _less_ flexibil=
ity in this area
than both Easymock and jMock).

One of the things I do val=
ue most with record/play frameworks is the
ability to ctrl+space your inter=
faces from your tests. The refactoring
part is not _as_ important once the =
interface has settled a bit but
still nice. I understand your point about t=
he niceness of not having
to specify the methods before you have settled on=
 them better after
your last mail,  at least when you are extending existin=
g interfaces
(that already have some implementations). I still prefer the a=
blity to
complete my methods it has become a natural way to wiork for me, i=
n
this case i think it boils down to personal preferences.

All the best
/J=
oakim Ohlrogge
